title: History of Israel (1948–present)

question: What was the main source of foreign currency for Egypt that was nationalized by President Nasser?

title: History of Israel (1948–present)
S: Israel was to attack Egypt, and Britain and France would then call on both sides to withdraw.
question: What was the plan of Britain, France, and Israel to seize the Suez Canal?
answer: Israel would attack Egypt, and Britain and France would then call on both sides to withdraw.

title: History of Israel (1948–present)
S: Despite heavy casualties, the Palestinians claimed victory, while Fatah and the PLO (of which it formed part) became famous across the Arab world.
question: What was the outcome of the conflict between Palestinians and Israelis?
answer: The Palestinians claimed victory and Fatah and the PLO became famous across the Arab world.

title: History of Israel (1948–present)
S: In early 1969 Levi Eshkol died in office of a heart attack and Golda Meir became Prime Minister with the largest percentage of the vote ever won by an Israeli party, winning 56 of the 120 seats after the 1969 election.
question: Who became the Prime Minister of Israel after Levi Eshkol's death?

title: History of Israel (1948–present)
S: In 1983 the May 17 Agreement was signed between Israel and Lebanon, paving the way for an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanese territory through a few stages.
question: What was the May 17 Agreement?
answer: The May 17 Agreement was signed between Israel and Lebanon, paving the way for an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanese territory through a few stages.

title: History of Israel (1948–present)
S: Later that year, the Israeli electoral system was changed to allow for direct election of the prime minister.
question: What was changed in the Israeli electoral system?
answer: The Israeli electoral system was changed to allow for direct election of the prime minister.

title: History of Israel (1948–present)
S: On 13 September 1993, Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) signed the Oslo Accords (a Declaration of Principles) on the South Lawn of the White House.
question: What were the Oslo Accords?
answer: The Oslo Accords were a Declaration of Principles signed by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) on the South Lawn of the White House.

title: History of Israel (1948–present)
S: Israel only made limited ground gains until the launch of Operation Changing Direction 11, which lasted for three days with disputed results.

title: History of Israel (1948–present)
S: In 2007 education was made compulsory until the age of 18 for all citizens (it had been 16).
question: When was education made compulsory until the age of 18 for all citizens?
answer: Education was made compulsory until the age of 18 for all citizens in 2007.

title: History of Israel (1948–present)
S: In 1961 a Herut no-confidence motion over the resurfaced Lavon Affair led to Ben-Gurion's resignation.

answer: A Herut no-confidence motion over the resurfaced Lavon Affair led to Ben-Gurion's resignation.

title: History of Israel (1948–present)
S: In 2005, all Jewish settlers were evacuated from Gaza (some forcibly) and their homes demolished. Disengagement from the Gaza Strip was completed on 12 September 2005. Military disengagement from the northern West Bank was completed ten days later.
question: When was the disengagement from the Gaza Strip completed?
